channel.title: Bloomberg Markets
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Boeing Sees Need For 44,000 New Jets; Cautions on Slow Output
item.description: Boeing Co. predicted airlines will need 43,600 new aircraft over the next 20 years, with markets like China and Southeast Asia leading the push as greater prosperity gives more people the means to travel.
item.dc:creator: Julie Johnsson

media:content.media:description: Boeing 737 fuselages on railcars at Spirit AeroSystems' factory in Wichita, Kansas, US, on Monday, July 1, 2024. Boeing Co. agreed to buy back Spirit AeroSystems Holdings Inc. for $37.25 a share in an all-stock deal that values the supplier at $4.7 billion, unwinding a two-decade separation as the embattled US planemaker tries to fix its manufacturing defects.

item.title: Global Rate Limbo Reigns After 150 Days of Trump
item.description: Multiple central banks are set to keep interest rates frozen in the coming week while continuing to gauge the impact of trade disruptions instigated by US President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, Aug. 21, 2024. Chair Jerome Powell will usher in the next chapter in the Federal Reserve's inflation battle on Friday, when he's expected to set the table for an interest-rate cut while reassuring investors that policymakers can stave off a sharp economic slowdown.

item.title: Gundlach Is Latest to Sound Corporate Debt Alarms: Credit Weekly
item.description: DoubleLine Capital has its lowest-ever allocations to speculative-grade bonds now, because valuations just don’t reflect the risks.
item.dc:creator: Ethan M Steinberg

media:content.media:description: Jeffrey Gundlach, chief executive officer and chief investment officer of DoubleLine Group, during the Bloomberg Global Credit Forum in Los Angeles, California, US, on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. The world's credit markets are having a moment, but trade wars, persistent inflation and growing concern of a slowdown in the world's largest economy loom large.

item.title: Ecuador Expected to Delay Fee on Mining, Industry Says
item.description: Ecuador has indicated that it will consider delaying the implementation of a new mining fee estimated to generate $229 million annually, according to Rodrigo Darquea, vice president of the country’s mining chamber.
item.dc:creator: Stephan Kueffner

media:content.media:description: The entrance to the Bira mine in Zaruma, Ecuador, on Thursday, April 28, 2022. Illegal mining has polluted waterways and sinkholes are swallowing the colonial houses of Zaruma, an Ecuadorian town that was literally built on gold and aspires to be a UNESCO world heritage site.

item.title: Tim Walz Speaks on Minnesota Democrats Assassination
item.description: Minnesota Governor Tim Walz held a press conference on the assassination of two democratic Minnesota state lawmakers and their spouses who were shot Saturday. Walz said it was likely a targeted political attack by a suspect impersonating a police officer. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Nigeria’s Central Bank Halts Dividends, Bonuses for Some Banks
item.description: The Central Bank of Nigeria has ordered banks under regulatory forbearance to halt dividend payments, director bonuses, and foreign investments.
item.dc:creator: Emele Onu

media:content.media:description: Automobiles drive past the headquarters of the Nigerian central bank in Abuja, Nigeria, on Friday, Jan. 10, 2020. Revenue in Nigeria has fallen short of the government target by at least 45% every year since 2015, and shortfalls have been funded through increased borrowing.

item.title: Russia, China to Lead Construction of Two Kazakh Nuclear Plants
item.description: Kazakhstan has selected Russia’s Rosatom to lead a consortium for the construction of its first nuclear power plant. The China National Nuclear Corp. expected to be lead a group to build a second atomic facility.
item.dc:creator: Andrey Biryukov, Nariman Gizitdinov

media:content.media:description: Workers do welding on a part of a RITM-200 nuclear reactor at ZiO-Podolsk Machine-Building Plant, an enterprise of Russia's nuclear agency Rosatom machine-building unit, in the town of Podolsk in the Moscow region on Dec. 5, 2023.

item.title: Retailers Seen Using Stablecoins to Push Back Against Card Fees
item.description: Stablecoins have become one of the hottest buzzwords in the world of finance as of late with US lawmakers on the cusp of passing the first guidelines for mainstream use of the cryptocurrencies designed to mirror the dollar.
item.dc:creator: Emily Mason

media:content.media:description: A customer enters their pin number while making a chip and pin payment using a Visa Inc. payment card, via a Verifone Systems Inc. payment device at a restaurant in London, U.K., on Friday, May 22, 2015. Credit and debit cards that can be used by tapping the reader are gaining users, and mobile apps are set to further boost the popularity of contactless paying.

item.title: Johnson & Johnson CEO: 'We’re in the Golden Era of Medical Innovation'
item.description: Johnson & Johnson Chairman and CEO Joaquin Duato believes that we are now in a “golden era” of innovation, particularly in the United States. Venture capital plays a vital early-stage role, but big pharma provides the infrastructure and market access. We visit Johnson & Johnson's innovation facility in Spring House to see how its early-stage innovation ecosystem serves patients and the local economy. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: ‘Golden Era’ of Medication Meets Geopolitical Uncertainty
item.description: In this episode of Wall Street Week, we talk to a longtime diplomat and the CEO of Johnson & Johnson
item.dc:creator: David Westin

media:content.media:description: Joaquin Duato, chief executive officer of Johnson & Johnson, during a taping of Bloomberg Television's Chief Future Officer episode in Raritan, New Jersey, US, on Thursday, June 6, 2024. With J&J spinning off its consumer products division, their chief financial officer now helps lead a company entirely focused on innovative medicine and medical technology, requiring the deployment of billions in research and development, as well as strategic M&A.

item.title: Fear of Uncertainty Held S&P 500 Back From Record. Now It’s Real
item.description: For weeks, the S&P 500 Index has inched along near an all-time high despite encouraging economic signals, as Wall Street’s concerns about a rich stock market in the face of mounting global uncertainty kept buying in check.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova

item.title: Nigeria’s United Capital Expands Into Francophone West Africa
item.description: United Capital Plc launched an investment management business from Côte d’Ivoire to operate in eight countries across French-speaking West Africa, according to a statement to the Nigerian stock exchange.
item.dc:creator: Emele Onu

media:content.media:description: Commercial office buildings in the Central Business District (CBD) of Lagos, Nigeria, on Monday, Aug. 14, 2023. Nigerian President Bola Tinubu has declared a state of emergency to counter the rising cost of living and in early August announced a 500 billion naira package of measures to improve food supply, ease transportation costs and boost manufacturing. Photographer: Benson Ibeabuchi/Bloomberg

item.title: Banking’s Mediterranean Deal Flurry Widens With Novo Banco Sale
item.description: The wave of bank acquisitions washing over Southern Europe has reached Portugal.
item.dc:creator: Steven Arons, Sonia Sirletti

item.title: The Big Gulf AI Deal That's Divided the White House
item.description: What does AI dominance actually mean?
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: The White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. US President Donald Trump said he would be increasing tariffs on steel to 50% from 25%, saying the move would help protect American steelworkers during a visit to a United States Steel Corp. plant on Friday.

item.title: The Big Gulf AI Deal Dividing The White House (Podcast)
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

item.title: HSBC Hastens Search to Find Next Chairman as Tucker’s Exit Nears
item.description: With the clock ticking in the hunt for HSBC Holdings Plc’s next chairman, Europe’s largest bank is speeding its efforts to assemble a list of candidates for the role.
item.dc:creator: Harry Wilson, Donal Griffin, Ambereen Choudhury, Laura Noonan

item.title: ECB Within Reach of 2% Inflation Goal, Lagarde Tells Xinhua
item.description: The European Central Bank is approaching its goal for consumer-price growth, President Christine Lagarde said, warning of uncertainty emanating from US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde, president of the European Central Bank (ECB), at a rates decision news conference in Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, June 5, 2025. The ECB lowered interest rates for the eighth time in a year after inflation dipped beneath 2% and the economy suffered repeated blows from US tariffs. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: Influencer Marketing Gains Ground as Global Ad Budgets Tighten
item.description: Ashton Hall’s morning routine involves dunking his head in iced Saratoga Spring Water. For the company that sells the bottled water — Hall’s brand of choice for drinking, brushing his teeth and submerging himself — that’s fantastic news.
item.dc:creator: Chloe Meley, Maggie Shiltagh, Rachel Phua

item.title: Switzerland’s Likely Rate Cut to Zero Threatens to Test Banks
item.description: The Swiss National Bank’s next cut in borrowing costs may be about to cause a headache for banks, if officials end up experimenting with their first-ever interest rate of zero.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

item.title: Middle East Escalation, Lower Gas Prices, Johnson & Johnson, Flying Cars | Wall Street Week
item.description: This week, Richard Haass of Centerview Partners tells us what the escalation of geopolitical tension between Israel and Iran could mean for oil prices. And President Trump’s call for $2 gas may please consumers, but in oil towns like Odessa, falling prices threaten jobs, investment and the economic foundation of the US energy heartland. Plus, an interview with Johnson & Johnson’s CEO on the golden age of medical innovation. Later, will flying cars soon be a reality? (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Qualitas Health Weighs $942 Million Malaysian IPO, The Edge Says
item.description: Asian healthcare provider Qualitas Health Group is weighing an initial public offering that will raise as much as 4 billion ringgit ($942 million), according to a report in The Edge, citing sources with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Y-Sing Liau

media:content.media:description: The Bursa Malaysia in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Friday, May 23, 2025. Discount-chain Eco-Shop Marketing Bhd. debuts in Malaysia on Friday in a listing that’s set to create a billionaire after the nation’s biggest initial public offering of the year. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: Middle East Tensions Escalate, Oil Prices Jump
item.description: Centerview Partners Senior Counselor Richard Haass says that while geopolitical tensions cause fluctuations in prices, there would have to be ongoing conflict to see a sustained upward move in oil prices. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Stocks Sink, Oil Jumps as Mideast Tensions Build | The Close 6/13/2025
item.description: Bloomberg Television brings you the latest news and analysis leading up to the final minutes and seconds before and after the closing bell on Wall Street. Today's guests are John Bolton, Former US Ambassador, Rebecca Babin, CIBC Private Wealth Group, Stephen Trent, Citi, Bill Curtin, Hogan Lovells, Jess Menton, Bloomberg News, Jason Pride, Glenmede, Christopher Cain, Bloomberg Intelligence, Callie Cox, Ritzholtz Wealth Mgmt, Joe Cirincione, Center for International Policy, Andrew Kline, Park Lane, James Jeffrey, Former US Ambassador to Iraq & Turkey, Wendy Benjaminson, Bloomberg News. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Crystal Palace FC Backer Eagle Files Confidentially for US IPO
item.description: Eagle Football Holdings Ltd., one of the most active investors in football clubs globally, has filed confidentially for a US initial public offering.
item.dc:creator: David Hellier

media:content.media:description: Crystal Palace's midfielder Jeffrey Schlupp heads the ball during a match between Liverpool and Crystal Palace in Liverpool, England, on May 25, 2025.

item.title: Fmr US Amb to Iraq on Cconflict Between Israel-Iran
item.description: James Jeffrey, Former US Ambassador to Iraq & Turkey speaks with Romaine Bostick about the current conflict between Israel and Iran. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Sports Teams Now Run Like Tech Startups: Fmr. NFL Player
item.description: Andrew Kline, Park Lane Founder & Former St. Louis Rams Lineman speaks with Romaine Bostick about the rising valuations of sport teams. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: 23andMe Co-Founder Wins Auction for Genetic Data
item.description: The co-founder of bankrupt genetic analysis company 23andMe won an auction for the firm’s assets, agreeing, along with a California research institute, to pay $305 million for a cache of customer DNA data
item.dc:creator: Steven Church

media:content.media:description: Anne Wojcicki, chief executive officer and co-founder of 23andMe Inc., speaks during the 2020 Makers Conference in Los Angeles, California, U.S., on Tuesday, Feb. 11, 2020. The event gathers industry leading females for roundtable discussions to help inspire the women of tomorrow.

item.title: JPMorgan Readies $6.5 Billion Skechers Debt Sale for Next Week
item.description: JPMorgan Chase & Co. plans to kick off a $6.5 billion debt offering to support private equity firm 3G Capital’s purchase of footwear maker Skechers as soon as next week, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Jeannine Amodeo

media:content.media:description: Sneakers in a Skechers store in Times Square in New York, US, on Monday, May 5, 2025. Investment firm 3G Capital will acquire footwear maker Skechers USA Inc. for $8.2 billion, the company said in a statement on Monday.

item.title: Belgium’s Credit Rating Cut by Fitch as Budget Concerns Linger
item.description: Belgium’s sovereign credit was cut by Fitch Ratings, signaling an increase in uncertainty about the country’s ability to rein in years of substantial debt accumulation.
item.dc:creator: Michal Kubala, Lyubov Pronina

item.title: Columbia Graduate Still in Custody After Frantic Day of Appeals
item.description: A Columbia University graduate who participated in pro-Palestinian protests will remain in custody at an immigration facility after a federal judge said the government could detain him over alleged problems with his green card application.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Hurtado, Anika Arora Seth

media:content.media:description: Mahmoud Khalil Photographer: Selcuk Acar/Anadolu/Getty Images
